Each year Phillips Free Library Director Priscilla Berggren-Thomas runs a monthly lunch time book club for interested fifth graders. A free novel is provided to all participants each month.

Prior to the school closure, Miss Priscilla was able to distribute the novels for the rest of the year to club members!

Intermediate School Librarian Mrs. Totman created a Google Classroom for the club to chat about their books while they are home. The group recently finished discussing the March novel, The Door in the Alley by Adrienne Kress.

Some students even shared creative projects about the novel for other club members (pictured below)!

What an awesome way to continue an amazing partnership between the Intermediate School and the public library for in-home learning!

This school year we are again partnering with Guthrie Cortland Medical Center to provide nurse practitioner services to students in our district!

The nurse practitioner program provides a number of medical services that are otherwise unavailable in the district. Services a nurse practitioner can provide include the ability to attain a physical, receive a diagnosis for an illness, and/or order necessary medication without a student needing to go see a doctor.

Parents must opt-in to this service through a consent form that is available at all schools in the district.

Check out this video to get to know Anna, one of the outstanding nurses at Guthrie Medical explain the different medical services she can provide!

Read more about the program here:
http://www.homercentral.org/districtpage.cfm?pageid=1454

The fun never stops here at Homer! Check out this slideshow from Mrs. Exelby's class participating in an egg drop!

Students were split in to groups and had to protect their eggs from a one story drop with a handful of supplies!

The students came up with a plan and created a protection device with the materials provided. Then came time for the ultimate test!

Following the conclusion of the experiment the students discussed their strategies and how different components of their plan impacted the outcome of the drop.

It was an informative (and sometimes messy) experiment!
